Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bringing NSF MARGINS/GeoPRISMS Continental Margins Research into the Undergraduate Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project is bringing high-priority science results and data from the NSF-funded MARGINS program, an interdisciplinary study of the processes and evolution of continental margins, into undergraduate geoscience courses. The project team, comprising experts in continental-margin research and geoscience education, is working with a user community to create, assess and disseminate a coherent set of modular mini-lessons and course segments for upper-division courses that engage students with cutting-edge findings on rupturing continental lithosphere, subduction processes, seismogenesis, and sediment dispersal from sources to sinks.

The Intellectual Merit of this project lies in the integration of research and education by transforming high-quality MARGINS science into educational resources for undergraduate classrooms. The Broader Impacts of this project lie in the multi-institutional effort to disseminate MARGINS science, offering scientists a powerful means of increasing the impact of their own research, while creating portable curricular resources to educate and engage geoscience students across a range of courses and institutional types.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative science education research project was tasked with bringing major science results from the NSF-funded decadal MARGINS program into undergraduate geoscience courses. The mini-lesson project team, comprised of experts in continental-margins research and geoscience education, worked with a user community to create, assess, and disseminate the mini-lessons. The result is fifteen data-rich class exercises (available at http://serc.carleton.edu/margins/index.html) that summarize the results of dozens of research investigations at multiple global focus sites across four primary research initiatives: Rupturing Continental Lithosphere (RCL), Subduction Factory (SubFac), Seismogenic Zone Experiment (SEIZE), and Source to Sink (S2S). The lessons explore tectonic, structural, geochemical, and sedimentary processes along continental margins. They will ensure that geoscience students are not only aware of the geological principles that formed these complex areas, but will have a greater understanding of the importance of these areas relative to natural resources (e.g. oil reserves) and natural hazards (e.g. tsunamis).

 The Intellectual Merit of this project lies in the integration of research and education by transforming high-quality MARGINS science into educational resources for undergraduate classrooms. The Broader Impacts of this project lie in the multi-institutional effort to disseminate MARGINS science, offering scientists a powerful means of increasing the impact of their own research, while creating portable curricular resources to educate and engage geoscience students across a range of courses and institutional types. The mini-lessons are available to the general public and will serve to raise awareness of the importance of geoscience to our understanding of the evolution of the Earth, resources, and natural hazards.
